title: Will Nawaz Sharif, whose family was recently implicated in the Panama Papers, cease to be Prime Minister of Pakistan in 2016?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Am  closing this one out from 1 to 0.  Timing on the one hand in resolution terms &, Sharif might even find himself @ Trump's inauguration ceremony if he gets an invitation. Whether new President sends along an "official invitation" is an interesting question but, Sharif would sure like to go in any event!
http://indianexpress.com/article/world/world-news/pakistan-prime-minister-nawaz-sharif-donald-trump-president-oath-taking-ceremony-tariq-fatemi-may-visit-us-next-month-4410095/
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

http://tribune.com.pk/story/1238914/army-ends-retirement-guessing-game/
“COAS [Chief of Army Staff] kicks off his farewell visits beginning from Lahore today. Meets, addresses [and] thanks a huge gather(ing) of soldiers from the army and Rangers,” Lt-Gen Asim Saleem Bajwa said in a Twitter post, dampening speculation that the army chief might receive an extension when his three-year term ends this month. http://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/columns/nawaz-sharif-pakistan-army-chief-gen-raheel-sharif-retires-4388365/
Pakistan’s prime ministers have the formal right to “appoint” army chiefs, but did not seem to enjoy the power to “terminate” their services. Having risked a lot during his earlier tenure to affirm the right to hire and fire the army chiefs, PM Sharif has refrained from rushing into a decision that could cost him his current office. When he boldly replaced General Pervez Musharraf in October 1999 after the failed Kargil putsch by the army chief in the summer of that year, PM Sharif found himself in a prison and then a near-decade-long exile in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. Given that background, it is quite remarkable that PM Sharif avoided giving an extension to General Sharif. http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/pakistan/General-Sharif-a-known-India-baiter-on-way-out/articleshow/55552299.cms
According to government and military sources, the name of the next Army chief has been finalized with consent of the COAS, but it has been decided the name would be disclosed just before Gen Sharif 's retirement on Nov 29. Dropping from 20% to 3%. Will go to 1% after his retirement.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

There is only limited momentum to the movement against PM Sharif. The leader of the call-to-impeachment is cricketer-turned-politician Imran Khan and the movement seems to enjoy support from the outgoing Supreme Court Chief Justice as well as head of the Army.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Head fake! Nawaz Sharif expected to survive
Information Minister offered as the sacrificial lamb giving the Prime Minister some breathing space, bringing estimates back down
Up 7% at least until I see how the Khan protests evolve.

Did Kahn and company make it the ground of the Presidential residence? If they are allowed through it will signal that the military is about to take over again till they can put their own man up. If not then they will be signaling that they are content with the figure head president they have now.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
On second thought, since the risk will drop steeply in the month following Raheel's retirement or extension (scheduled for Nov 30), I ought to go slightly higher than 15%.

Maintaining 15%.
Regardless of the various stories floating around, I am confident that if Nawaz steps down or is removed, it will be due to Raheel and the Army. Therefore, as soon as we have clarity on Raheel's retirement, I may take this forecast down.

November 2 protests will hopefully give us a better picture of where this is likely to go. Still think Nawaz is safe, but there is too much smoke around at the moment to warrant a zero forecast:
http://tribune.com.pk/story/1214307/rivals-trying-seize-sabotage-countrys-progress-pm-nawaz/

Rumours, rumours, rumours! Better to be safe than sorry
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Maintaining 15% forecast, at least until there is clarity on Raheel's extension or retirement.
http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ani/military-boys-set-timer-device-on-nawaz-sharif-govt-116101500461_1.html "Islamabad is now bracing itself for the inevitable. There was a gossamer coup of 2014 where Raheel Sharif took charge of foreign policy and security matters but left the rest to Nawaz. But now the distance between PMO and GHQ is too vast to be bridged. Raheel Sharif retires on 30th November and speculations were rife whether he would get an extension or fade away into the sunset. But the fact is that a General is a General till the day he superannuates. Especially so in Pakistan. Nawaz Sharif probably miscalculated that Raheel was a lame duck. If anything Raheel is now a wounded tiger, a dangerous beast." "While the print media in Pakistan is still leaning on supporting Dawn and by and large supports the elected government, television studios and the Urdu media have started the migration towards the army. "

UPDATE: 1% forecast remains unchanged. Here is why. Comment:  Time is now is of the essence.  There are approximately (80) days left to resolution of this GJ Q.  To date, Nawaz Sharif has proved to be a "foxy" character, politically & physically speaking. He has survived a heart issue. (FN1)  He has survived internal political attacks. (2). He has more recently acted v Prime Ministerial  @ the UN in NYC making his case on Kashmir. (3). He is about to make a SIGNIFICANT decision on General Raheel Sharif (4). This critical decision has once again heated up the sensitive issue of who in Pakistan is actually in charge this past week when a travel ban was placed on journalist Cyril Almeida (5). Sharif continues to make political waves w/ Modi on the various cross border issues, primarily Kashmir. (6) IMPORTANTLY, administration makes the case, Pakistan is making economic progress &, continuing to extend itself b/y its borders w/ important Partners such as Russia & China. (7) Conclusion: The Panama Papers controversy carries less immediate intensity (8), when viewed from the above referenced perspective as Sharif as attempts to "manage" to his advantage.  Physically & politically he has survived to date. Considering the above-mentioned timing issue, there is a high probability he will continue at, least through resolution date of this Q.  @Khalid's recent response to @AndrewSabisky 's query is instructive military appointment, which does carry significant implications inasmuch as we are addressing the Pakistan situation. Considering the flashpoint capabilities Pakistan carries, the next sixty days are worth covering closely. Sources////
(1) https://m.geo.tv/#category%7Clatest-news%7Cp106813-Indian-Prime-Minister-Modi-wishes-Nawaz-Sharif-speedy-recovery
(2) http://tribune.com.pk/story/1194918/opposition-lawmakers-urge-govt-shun-non-state-actors/
(3) http://indianexpress.com/article/world/world-news/full-text-of-nawaz-sharifs-speech-at-the-un-general-assembly-3043041/
(4) http://indianexpress.com/article/world/world-news/full-text-of-nawaz-sharifs-speech-at-the-un-general-assembly-3043041/
(5) http://m.ndtv.com/world-news/pakistani-journalist-who-reported-military-government-rift-banned-from-leaving-country-1472698; http://m.hindustantimes.com/world-news/nawaz-sharif-orders-action-over-news-story-on-national-security/story-hUizPziP8U344V30WXnUyL.html; http://m.dw.com/en/why-pakistani-pm-sharif-should-replace-the-army-chief/a-36014438;
(6)http://www.hngn.com/articles/210978/20161010/kashmir-nawaz-sharif-pakistan-india-kashmir-freedom-struggle-surgical-strike-pakistan-burhan-wani.htm
(7) http://www.financialexpress.com/india-news/closer-us-india-ties-reason-for-pakistans-burgeoning-ties-with-russia-nawaz-sharifs-special-envoy-on-jk/411215/; https://m.geo.tv/#category%7Clatest-news%7Cp117215-PM-says-CPEC-to-bring-economic-revolution-in-Pakistan;
(8) https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/156348-Bilawal-criticises-PM-Nawaz-for-blocking-Panama-Papers-investigation
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Some major moves are afoot in Pakistan, raising the risk for the PM.
http://www.news18.com/news/world/tensions-rise-as-pak-govt-blames-its-army-for-spoiling-countrys-image-1299231.html
"...the younger Sharif complained that whenever action has been taken against certain groups by civilian authorities, the security establishment has worked behind the scenes to set the arrested free. Astounded onlookers describe a stunned room that was immediately aware of the extraordinary, unprecedented nature of the exchange." PM may have taken the Army on board before making his move which reduces the risk for him a little bit, “According to several government officials, Monday’s confrontation was part of a high-stakes gamble by Prime Minister Sharif to try and forestall further diplomatic pressure on Pakistan. In separate meetings with the army chief, participants describe an animated and energised Sharif, who has argued that Pakistan faces real isolation if policy adjustments are not made,” Moving 10% to 15%. With just 3 months left, I don't think I can raise it any further based on news provided by anonymous sources. Will probably reduce from now on as time passes.
Looks increasingly unlikely but the India situation can lead to it! Never know. Cutting probability nevertheless
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

2016 is nearly over.
Reducing the probability accordingly.

Present situation, with the 'surgical strikes' being claimed by India, is highly unpredictable for at least the next week or so. 
Raising from 5% to 10% until dust settles.
There has been little, if any impact. Everyone seems to be made of Teflon these days.

CAVEAT:
Interesting piece. INS JANE Intelligence analyst cautioned impossible to be definitive about site's fundamental purpose on imagery alone. Date: 16. September 2016 um 16:45:45 MESZ Subject: Pakistan MAY be building new nuclear complex: analysts Comment: PM Narwaz Sharif travels to NY shortly to take part in a UN Conference where he is scheduled to address the Kashmir issue as this age old dispute btw India & Pakistan heats up, again. IHS JANES intelligence is well known in the industry. NB attached. Whether Pakistan is GEARING UP its nuclear arsenal is an OPEN QUESTION & certainly NOT on the agenda but, the timing & release of this piece "conjecturing probabilities" reference Sharif's visit provides interesting geopolitical cross examination by interested parties on just how far advanced Pakistan is on this issue. Pakistan may be building new nuclear complex: analysts from AFP news agency’s Tweet 
https://sg.news.yahoo.com/pakistan-may-building-nuclear-complex-analysts-101308429.html?soc_src=social-sh&soc_trk=tw "...Karl Dewey, a proliferation analyst at IHS Jane's added: "It is sited within an established centrifuge facility, has strong security and shows some of the structural features of a possible new uranium enrichment facility. This makes it a strong candidate for a new centrifuge facility."
The structure of the site also bears strong resemblance to facilities built by nuclear fuel company URENCO which also operates several nuclear plants in Europe, it said.
"This may be more than coincidence as A.Q. Khan, considered by many to be the founder of Pakistan’s nuclear programme, worked at URENCO before stealing centrifuge designs and returning to Pakistan," said Charlie Cartwright, an imagery analyst for IHS Jane's.."
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/articleshow/54206564.cms?utm_source=contentofinterest&utm_medium=text&utm_campaign=cppst ""At least some of Pakistan's top brass are reportedly unsatisfied with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, blaming his government for ineffective rule or labelling him unfit for a variety of other reasons," he [a top American think-tank expert] said.  Over the past six months, there has been media speculation that the prime minister might step down because of his failing health or because his family was implicated in the Panama Papers scandal, or that the current army chief, General Raheel Sharif, might be granted an extension rather than handing over his baton in November as scheduled. "Simultaneously, political opposition parties are once again campaigning for Nawaz Sharif's ouster. In short, it is difficult to predict precisely who will be running Pakistan when America's next president takes office," he said.  "Under similar conditions in decades past, Pakistan might be ripe for a coup, he noted. Now the military is playing a savvier game, pulling the nation's strings from behind a curtain so as to avoid the taint of dictatorship and, perhaps more importantly, to shirk its responsibility for improving the quality of governance. "But this puppet show may not be so easily sustained. Political turmoil has considerable disruptive potential in the short run. More worrisome, a sham democracy will have dangerous vulnerabilities over the long run, depriving the state of popular legitimacy in the midst of an existential confrontation with Islamist.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  @Khalid, do you have any new thoughts that you'd care to share?

Given any random year of civilian rule, chance of a coup would have to be about 10%. This is especially true when the Army has been out of power for an extended period, at least in a de jure sense even if it is not true on de facto grounds. Since only about 30% of 2016 is left, the probability ought to be around 2-3% at this stage. However, this year there is increased pressure on the Balochi front as well as in international circles on terrorism, and the Army might step in if Nawaz blinks. So perhaps the base rate should be 15-20%,  instead of 10%. Then the probability with four months left would be 5-7%. Raising from 2% to 5%.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

given the current tensions & mass human rights violations in Baloch & other parts like Sindh in pakistan, a tacit Military coup could take place, leading to a change in the prime minister's chair. i put this possibility at 45%

Date: 3. September 2016 um 10:44:47 MESZ Subject: PM Offers General Raheel Sharif Two Key Posts / Karachi Schism More Trouble for Nawaz Sharif Am moving down 1% from 2%. Here is why. Comment: On the one hand, PM Nawaz Sharif is making every reasonable appearance of being able to overcome health and, domestic political opponent issues. He is, arguably, looking more Prime Ministerial as time passes relative to initiation of this GJ Q. On the other hand, the recent events surrounding Altaf Hussain ( leader of Muttahida Qaumi Movement) living in exile in London make clear PM Sharif still manages to survive in the TROUBLED WATERS of Pakistan. (2) In support of the argument that he will remain Prime Minister through year end, he is now scheduled to make a two/three week trip to the U.S.beginning 13/9/16 where, among other visits, he will address the UN GENERAL ASSEMBLY on Pakistan issues including the thorny issue of Kashmir.  Whether he ALSO makes his IMPORTANT  decision on the future Chief of Army Staff General beforehand, is an open question. NB attached(1). What is clear, however, is PM Sharif is making every effort to keep the still powerful yet controversial Raheel Sharif " in the fold" with this weekends new offer of two key posts, which are up for his consideration. Conclusion:
There remains approximately one hundred & twenty days to resolution of this GJ Q. Geopolitically speaking, that is still a great deal of time. On the one hand, Pakistan is Pakistan & Nawaz Sharif is Nawaz Sharif so, a lot can happen without significant notice.  On the other hand, every piece of circumstantial evidence since his health issues continues to support the hypothesis that Nawaz Sharif will do what is necessary to remain PM through 2016. (1) http://www.onlinenews.com.pk/index.php?page=newsdetail&news_id=4982 "...
The CoAS did not respond to the government offer yet , but the reliable sources said that Prime Minister who is going to USA on 13 September, wants to resolve the issue  that which seat is suitable for General Raheel Sharif before leaving  for America . As PM Nawaz Sharif would go on almost 20 days foreign  visit as before going to USA he would also stay at London for a short time where he would undergo his medical check-up. The political and diplomatic circles are giving special importance to PM’s visit to USA.  As the speech of Prime Minister in the United Nations General Assembly  and his meetings with international leaders  would define the future policy of Pakistan .
The analysts have the opinion that at present USA is completely tilting towards India and Afghanistan , whereas on the other hand Pak- China relations are on its peak. Though the meeting of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif  is not fixed with his Indian counterpart Modi during the US visit , but any surprise breakthrough  is  not out of question , by keeping  in view the good mental coordination between the two leaders.    
The close aide of Nawaz Sharif advised him to settle the issue regarding fate  of military command , as Chief of Army Staff General Raheel Sharif would retire from service on 29 November this year after completing tenure in GHQ..." (2) http://app.ft.com/cms/s/de85d57c-69c5-11e6-a0b1-d87a9fea034f.html
Down 5% for scoring purposes. (For a time at least.)
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Reducing 8% from 10 to 2%. Here is why. Comment: My originally cautious forecast was based on medical uncertainty. Having given approximately ninety days (90) since this original May forecast, these medical uncertainties continue to be reduced.  We now have more circumstantial evidence & know  more about his abilities to sustain a Prime Minister agenda. For example, on the one hand, Nawaz Sharif  is politically combative, if not particularly cautious on the message of support to Kashmiri people recently (Footnote 1). With India's PM Modi pushing back on the Balochistan issue,  PM Sharif is certainly NOT signaling weakness and, will forcefully raise the Kasmir issue at the UN General Assembly in September. (2) Finally, on the geopolitical front, Modi recently warned it will become more assertive on its claims to Pakistan controlled areas of Kasmir, a key transit point to the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor. (3)  On the other hand, domestically, he continues to push the economic stability agenda which is further supportive of his changing, more active hands on roll  both internationally and, within Pakistan.(4)  Additionally, on the all important appointment of the new Chief of the Army Staff General ( presently Raheel Sharif ) decision, PM Sharif has made clear, ALTHOUGH he will be the decision maker, he is certainly SUBJECT TO military influence  as well.(5)   WHEN this decision will be made is an open Question. (5) The succession is scheduled to take place upon General Sharif's retirement, end of November.  Conclusion:  With slightly more than One Hundred & Twenty (120) left to RESOLUTION of this GJ Q, considering all the above-mentioned issues, the probabilities have increased measurably that Sharif can hold out for another four months.  Each one of these domestic & geopolitical above referenced issues when considered as a whole, portray an individual that has every intention of doing what IS NECESSARY to remain "in office". Like anyone else, an unexpected event resulting in his death is possible. Therefore, 0% forecast is from my perspective inappropriate.  Sources:
(1) http://www.newsnation.in/article/143183-nawaz-sharif-vows-to-support-struggle-of-kashmiri-people.html?WORLD ; (2) http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/pm-narendra-modi-crossed-red-line-by-talking-about-balochistan-pakistan/articleshow/53755806.cms ; (3) http://www.stripes.com/news/indian-prime-minister-sends-warning-shot-to-china-pakistan-on-territory-spat-1.424361 ; (4) http://tribune.com.pk/story/1168912/country-approaching-fiscal-stability-nawaz/ (5) http://m.ndtv.com/world-news/pakistan-pm-nawaz-sharif-bows-to-army-makes-zamir-defence-secretary-1450675; http://m.ndtv.com/world-news/nawaz-sharif-to-decide-on-successor-to-pak-army-chief-raheel-sharif-report-1444188 ; https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/142397-PM-keeps-his-cards-close-to-his-chest
Time heals all wounds! especially in politics in these parts

Down from 10%.
Opposition is all sound and fury, not getting anywhere. My only remaining concern was whether Sharif's recent heart surgery would result in his job becoming too strenuous, but so far that doesn't appear to be the case, especially as he has some trusted proxies within his government to share the burden.
Dropping 5% to be approximately at the consensus.

Mere corruption, especially as it involves family members, is no reason for hasty action in Pakistan. Nonetheless, PM of Pakistan has not historically been a long-term gig.

He  knows  how to use social media and remains nation's most popular leader.  Al Jazz link here  http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2016/05/nawaz-sharif-viable-option-pakistan-160530095043904.html

NO change in present forecast. That said should additional HEALTH related issues arise, will adjust upwards. Date: 23. Juli 2016 um 10:33:32 MESZ Subject: Dailytimes | Ex-PM says Pakistan can’t tolerate a military coup now COMMENT: Continue to believe this GJ turns on HEALTH issues not, on  political or military considerations. His health issues continue to take a center stage, at this point.  On the one hand considering his health issues, Sharif finally 
made it to  Islamabad Friday to conduct meetings with military officials. http://tribune.com.pk/story/1146988/pm-nawaz-presides-top-security-huddle-islamabad/. This was done is spite of physician recommendations to cancel the meetings. http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/nawaz-sharif-resumes-duties-in-islamabad-against-doctors-advice-1434463?site=full. The trip had been delayed due to leg infection & fever. http://app.ft.com/cms/s/d2d11974-4d7f-11e6-88c5-db83e98a590a.html On the other hand, considering the political/military issues, post the failed Military Coup in Turkey, FORWARD LOOKING "probability options" when geopolitical changes are afoot, should be considered.  Reference Turkey.  There is always a discounting mechanism at work so, being a bit more imaginative about the Status Quo political environment is, only being reasonable. Thus, recently the Former PM indicated the Country can't tolerate a military coup at this state.http://dailytimes.com.pk/pakistan/17-Jul-16/ex-pm-says-pakistan-cant-tolerate-a-military-coup-now . Additionally, AUGUST is an important decision making period as Sharif is expected to finalize the successor of Chief of Army Staff (COAS) General Raheel. http://dailytimes.com.pk/islamabad/23-Jul-16/most-difficult-decision-awaits-nawaz-sharif-in-august Conclusion: MIXED bag. Definitely believe CRITICAL Q  remains:  Whether Narwaz Sharif is presently emotionally willing & physically - medically able to hold out through year end as PM ? 
The MORE one is subjected to  standard operating procedure Government approved news disclosure for public dissemmination status quo response to the above-mentioned Q...the more CREATIVE one can & should become with the following Qs: 1. What are the probabilities Sharif is neither emotionally or physically fit to assume his PM responsibilities through year end? 
2. Why not consider such a possibility in the light of the non stop consensus view voiced by above-mentioned sources? 
3. Isn't it ...always something... that has never happened before or, is not supposed to happen that causes the greatest impact? 
4. Since his return to Pakistan, there has been an almost one sided " post op" meme PM Sharif is improving, it will take time, he is now working, making decisions et cetera, flow of news from limited sources ( family, pro- ruling party government &, general medical update understandably "w/o medical specificity" on his exact physical condition ). 
5. Isn't this NOTHING less than begging the issue of STATUS QUO? Many Qs w/o clear evidence. Will reman focused on this issue for the time being w/o counter-veiling proof substantiating the fundamental Q above mentioned.

follow up on health issues. According to the below link he also has a fever. was his heart rate >90, resp rate >20, or white blood cell count >12,000? You need two of the criteria to be SIRS positive. If so then he has SIRS. Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS). SIRS is the pre-cursor to septic shock. I have seen people go from SIRS to Septic Shock and die within 24 hours. If he makes it 72 hours from the initial fever then he will probably be ok b/c he is being appropriately treated.  maintaining 0% http://pk.shafaqna.com/EN/32369
http://www.mdcalc.com/sirs-sepsis-and-septic-shock-criteria/
More info, according to the article the infection is not serious:  http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-nawaz-sharif-resumes-duties-in-islamabad-against-doctors-advice-2236853

Another reason to go back up again: "Politicians nervous as Imran Khan pushes for army takeover in Pakistan" From the article: "On July 17, while addressing a public rally in Islamgarh in Pakistan-occupied Kashmir, Khan said, “Democracy in Pakistan is threatened by Nawaz’s monarchy and the people will celebrate and distribute sweets if the army takes over.”" "But a buzz has been created for an army takeover in Pakistan. People in Islamabad have seen a clear pattern emerging which is reminiscent of earlier occasions when the army deposed elected governments." Source: http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/politicians-nervous-as-imran-khan-pushes-for-army-takeover-in-pakistan/story-WtIxYXJ8LE5WXJb9OIaB0J.html
Not that big issue in PAK politics strong enough to get him out of his position. But yes, it made him weaker.
Passage of time without any noticeable reactions means less odds of it happening. None of the opposition leaders have been able to make much hay of this as all of them have their own baggage.

- 2 from 27 Time is going by, seems to be only discussions about the terms fo reference «ToR» for the Panama Inquiry Commission.
'Before this, MQM had not been a part of the united opposition's last meeting or the latest meeting of the parliamentary committee for preparing the terms of reference.   https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/134556-MQM-decides-to-attend-united-opposition-meeting

Nawaz is back in the country and shows no signs of an impending exit.
Dropping from 10% to 5%.

Down from 25%.  First indications after his return from abroad are that he will most probably take on his critics. Even if he himself won't be as physically active as before, he has several proxies in the form of close family and kitchen cabinet members to do the needful. It certainly doesn't look like he's thinking of stepping aside this year, and there are no signs of the Army wanting a change at this time - there's no clear alternative for them right now. http://www.dawn.com/news/1270514 - PM advised to get tough with PTI "A PML-N politician from Lahore remarked that “the PM’s body language is that of a leader determined to stand firm against his opponents”.
“He is in no mood to show leniency,” he said. Most of the people the prime minister had met recently had advised him to discard his old ‘soft’ approach and get tough with Mr Khan in particular, he added. These advisers were of the view that “defensive tactics” of the prime minister had served to embolden the PTI over time."

I'm not worried about the Eighteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Pakistan which basically prevents the Pakistan President from removing the PM.  The only way by law to remove the is for the Parliament to have a vote of no confidence with at least a 20% of the electorate.  But then you have the Military who could kill him or he could die of natural causes.  I don't think either will happen rather elections will be held and he will leave office in the Spring of 2017.  The last few PMs were around 66-67 years old when they left office and their time as PM was about 3 years.  Sharif meets both of those criteria.    Gen Sharif says he will retire Nov 2016 as planned.  I suppose PM Nawaz Sharif will stay in power to appoint the new General in Nov.  I suppose this will be interesting politics considering the Panama papers, his surgery, and considering he is towards the end of his stent as PM. http://www.dawn.com/news/1235421/gen-raheel-sharif-puts-speculations-to-rest-says-will-retire-on-due-date?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+dawn-news+(Dawn+News)
Down 5% to be closer to consensus and for passage of time.

There's no chink in his standing. I think his third stint is going to be substantially better, undoing some of the damage he did in his earlier stints. This should keep the educated middle-class happier, while the conservatives don't have too many other places to turn.

Down 5 to 15% Date: 8. Juli 2016 um 07:46:58 MESZ Subject: Preparations underway for PM Nawaz's return to Pakistan - ARY NEWSARY NEWS COMMENT:

Nawaz exit scare receded, PM heading back home

Sharif has now been absent for almost a month because of his operation, and seems still to be firmly in charge. Various media outlets both inside and outside Pakistan are swinging behind him (perhaps as other players in the region realise that his strong leadership presents the best chance of keeping a lid on the insurgency in Pakistan, and preventing it from spilling over). Moreover, the opposition have failed to make significant gains: a petition calling for his removal on the grounds of corruption was recently presented, but seems to be gaining little popular (or legal) traction; attempts to declare his absence unconstitutional are also not making progress. A letter supposedly written by Sharif personally opposing India's admission to the Nuclear Suppliers Group is also being heavily publicised in Pakistan - this is a highly populist move designed to shore up popular support throughout the country. The longer Sharif can hang on in his absence, the more likely it is that he will remain PM. If his position continues to strengthen, and the opposition continues to fail to gain ground, then I will revise this prediction further down in a few weeks.

Sharif is 67 and has a history of heart problems. He had successful open heart surgery in London in June, 2016 (his second visit to London for medical attention in 2016), but his health problems and the protracted absences from Pakistan that they have caused have led to calls for an interim Prime Minister to be elected in his stead in the last month. An attempt by Ishaq Dar, the Pakistani finance minister, to act as PM in Sharif's absence have triggered a constitutional crisis, leading to demands for his immediate return to office. There is some speculation that this is a ploy by the opposition to force Sharif's hand - if he is not well enough to return to office, and another cannot act as PM in his place, then this could trigger an immediate general election, or at least the official appointment of a caretaker PM. Moreover, dynastic politics are important in Pakistan. Sharif's daughter is believed to be poised to assume leadership of his own political dynasty after he steps down. There is a chance, therefore, that the combined pressure of his health problems and mounting political opposition may lead him to stand down if doing so enhances his dynasty's chances of returning to power in the future (he has, himself, returned to power twice following his first term of office). Above all, since the end of military rule in 2002 (not counting caretaker prime ministers), Prime Ministers of Pakistan have remained in office for an average of 21 months - Sharif has already served 36.  This suggests that there is a reasonable chance of Sharif not being PM by the end of 2016. On the other hand, the Panama Papers scandal is unlikely to damage him too severely: he has weathered corruption storms in the past, as have several of Pakistan's leading political figures. Sharif's approval ratings were extremely high throughout 2014 and 2015 (driven by heavy investment in popular public works projects), and have not dipped significantly. Whilst there has been a degree of international outcry, the impact of the scandal has been limited within Pakistan itself. If it were to have a significant effect (which seems unlikely at present), this would be felt at the ballot box, and the next (scheduled) general election will not be until 2018. Perhaps the most compelling evidence is that Sharif still enjoys the grudging support of the armed forces. The rapprochement that he has championed between military and civil leadership seems likely to safeguard his position. Moreover, the ongoing Taliban insurgency has served to occupy the army, and has united the political and security sectors in Pakistan in a shared cause. Although the military has, on several occasions, intervened in Pakistani politics, it is unlikely, in the short term at least, that Sharif will be removed in a military coup. Therefore, if Sharif ceases to be PM in Pakistan before the end of 2016, it is most likely that he will step down because of his health rather than because of pressure brought to bear as a result of the Panama Papers revelations. His health problems are serious (minimum recovery time from open heart surgery is 6 weeks; for a man of his age, in his condition, it could reasonably be expected to be longer), and the opposition have proved effective so far in preventing a proxy from taking power in his stead. If Sharif cannot return to power quickly, therefore, there is a good chance that he may have no choice but to step down. However, if he can hang on for the next two months and return, visibly and actively, to office, then there is a very good chance that he will be able to consolidate his position and remain in power for 2016. Therefore, if Sharif is still in power at the end of August, I will revise my prediction down.

Date: 20. Juni 2016 um 09:21:24 MESZ Subject: PM still needs to recover from operation: Daily Pakistan editor Mujib Shami - Daily Pakistan Global No change.   COMMENT: Interesting note from Daily Pakistan. NB below. "What really happened to the PM? Daily Pakistan reveals PM's complete medical history for the first time ..." Exact medical records have NOT, as far as I can determine, been disclosed. General medical condition, yes. Operative procedure, yes. All of this information has been readily available to the public.  However, the message Mujibar Rehman Shami, Chief Editor of Daily Pakistan who recently visited Nawaz Sharif puts more detail on "EXPECTATIONS of return" to Pakistan. Quite "vague verbiage" could, should, & would language. Also, not particularly helpful ( put mildly!) for the source when the reader is "BAITED" w/ language "reveals PM's complete medical history for first time" only to find already well known statements of general medical condition. Additionally, the attached interview w/ the Chief Editor Shami, is in Pakistani so, can't be helpful on this front unfortunately. Decently long time frame but I did not want to forecast this question earlier, as predicting Pakistani politics is tougher than calling a coin toss. Ok, so Panama Papers is a big deal but by itself not enough to see Sharif going. However, vacating office for any reason counts. Health can be one. Panama Papers another. A coup - well there have been three earlier, though this is a low probability event to my mind. So three buckets. Panama Papers etc - 60%, Health - 30% (half of P.P), Coup etc - 10% (one tenth of total). I give 40% of bucket 1 in toto, 50% of bucket 2 in toto, and 20% of bucket 3. Adding up - 24% + 15 + 2% = 41%. Hence 41%.

There are moves by the opposition for an investigation by a military body within the polity.  Whether the legislative action will pass or not in the lower house will depend on the minimum winning coalition for the PM.  If a military body does the investigation there is an unlikely chance that this matter will receive significant attention and problems for the PM.   The military is key to the minimum winning coalition. Notes from Wiki:   The Pakistani National Assembly (Urdu: قومی اسمبلئ پاکستان‎— Qaumī Asimbli'e Pākistān); is the lower house of the bicameral Majlis-e-Shura, which also comprises the President of Pakistan and Senate (upper house). The National Assembly and the Senate both convene at Parliament House in Islamabad. The National Assembly is a democratically elected body consisting of a total of 342 members who are referred to as Members of the National Assembly (MNAs), of which 272 are directly elected members and 70 reserved seats for women and religious minorities. A political party must secure 172 seats to obtain and preserve a majority.[4] Members are elected through the first-past-the-post system under universal adult suffrage, representing electoral districts known as National Assembly constituencies. According to the constitution, the 70 seats reserved for women and religious minorities are allocated to the political parties according to their proportional representation. Each National Assembly is formed for a five-year term, commencing from the date of the first sitting, after which it is automatically dissolved. The National Assembly can also be dissolved at any time by the President of Pakistan, upon the advice of the Prime Minister of Pakistan.  Note the authority of the PM regarding dissolving parliament .!

The current elected government has been in power for eight years. Since 1947 civilian governments have lasted respectively 11 years, 6 years and 11 years again before being overthrown by the military. So Pakistan's history suggests the possibility of a coup in the next few years. Lets start by assuming an even money chance of a coup sometime in the next four years. The allegations of corruption against Sharif's family suggest that a coup, if it is to happen, will more than likely occur for a publicly justifiable reason, and is therefore most likely in the remaining months of 2016, though early 2017 is still quite possible. Lets say that if it happens its an 80% chance of occurring in 2016. That lowers my assessment of the odds to 50%*80%=40%. However history also suggests that democracy is taking hold-2013 gave Pakistan the first civilian transfer of power after the successful completion of a five year term by a democratically elected government. Presumably also the military has a weather eye on the chaos that has ensued in the middle east after the overthrow of governments, albeit not democratic ones. I will arbitrarily calculate that each of these factors halves the potential risks and bring my forecast down to 40%*1/2*1/2=10%. The next  factor to consider is Sharif pledging to resign if found to be corrupt. At the moment he has plausible deniability as the allegations concern his family and not him. I believe that an inquiry will be under international pressure to keep Pakistan's democracy on track for fear of Pakistan's nuclear capabilities. Basis this I'll leave the odds where they are. However a couple of other possibilities to consider are 1) Sharif personally getting implicated as more documents are revealed and 2) Sharif being the victim of a plane crash, bombing or even his death from natural causes. I think these factors combined increase the odds by 1) 10% and 2) 3%. Total 23%
The power in Pakistan till resides in the army and the ISI. Very doubtful they would get rid of him, but they have removed others.
The only way,he can be removed is by the Army and that seems highly unlikely in 2016

Pakistan is facing large national security issues at the moment, namely from Islamic militancy (TPP), which American drones have been helping combat. National security will trump PM allegations for the public interest.

Various preference choices are possible for this particular outcome, which other forecasters have noted, could (and most likely)  have nothing to do with the Panama Papers itself.  This constrains the preference set to a small number of choices and consequently, with one outcome (leaving office), preferences over choices are an extremely small set.  Since corruption, patronage and de facto military/ruling elite coalition are prominent features of the Pakistani polity, one should expect that the PM's minimum winning coalition will remain in tact.    Therefore, given the function, g: X --> A  choices under conditions of certainty, require that {a1, ...., a(k)} be mapped topologically as one member of A to the outcome set X. X = {x1, ...,  x(n)}.  this constraint requires that the conditional action or choice in a maximized choice set suggest that the only option that would result in an outcome of the PM leaving office, is when he no longer has the support of the minimum winning coalition in the polity.   If this conditional outcome requires a negative action (or choice) compared to the previous preference, then the outcome will suggest a likely possibility that the PM will leave office.  However, given that the PM leaving office requires a choice set of A = {coercion, loss of a minimum coalition, and significant threat toward the PM}, this would be analytically and theoretically support leaving office.  However, given that corruption in Pakistan is deeply ingrained in its polity and the Panama Papers revelation has been open knowledge in Pakistan for some time, we can deduce with a high degree of confidence that the PM will not leave office.   While he is left with an uncomfortable option if explaining the matter, it does not change the actions and choice which will lead to him leaving office. The assumption that the question focuses on leaving office and NOT removed from office, it is sufficient to deduce that precision in the analytic process is not confused with actions and a choice set that require a different, if not larger choice set, among which could include assassination.  However, assassination over an insignificant matter demonstrate a level of absurdity that lead us to irrational decision making. Initial estimate :  5; estimate changed to 0.

Another US drone strike in Pakistan, this one killing somebody's favourite Taliban mullah.  Sooner or later the Pakistani military are going to tire of this, as it makes them look ineffectual.  (They may of course be covertly complicit, but it still makes them look ineffectual.)  They are not likely to smile upon a PM who permits This Sort of Thing.  The Panama Papers remain irrelevant unless the military use them as a pretext.  In the past, they have not much relied on pretexts.  Stay tuned.

Reducing from my initial 45% as it is beginning to look like Nawaz will be able to drag this out. However, there is considerable uncertainty, as the following op-ed indicates.. http://www.dawn.com/news/1259882/the-rack-or-the-knife (NB "the boys" is shorthand for the Army)
"HE’S gone. No, he’ll survive. He’ll definitely go. Maybe he’ll survive. He can’t survive. Maybe he’ll go. Gone, safe. In, out. Everyone’s got an opinion on Nawaz.
And why not? It’s the only show in town. Not quite death watch and not yet circus show, it’s depressing-riveting in a very Pakistani way. But with all the focus on the how, there’s something that’s been missed — why? There’s really three options for who — Nawaz, Imran or the boys. We all know why Nawaz could end up ousting himself — because, well, he’s Nawaz.
And we all know why Imran wants him gone — there can only be one prime minister and as long as someone else has that job, Imran doesn’t. But the boys are a bit more puzzling. What the hell could Nawaz have done to make them want to knock him out? Even the Nawaz camp seems unsure.
Unsure, but aggrieved. Convinced that it’s the boys who caused and are stoking the latest instability, the Nawaz coterie is indignant — we even let Musharraf go; what else do they want?"
Pak PM's are perpetually perched precariously.
Not enough international condemnation so far.

Sharif asked the opposition and other lawmakers to help form a parliamentary commission.
Previous efforts to have a retired or sitting Supreme Court judge chair a judicial commission have stalled as all the judges rejected the offer.
It is not clear if the opposition will take up Sharif’s latest offer. They walked out soon after Sharif stopped speaking, angered that seven questions they posed to him ahead of the parliamentary session were not answered.
“Not a single question has been answered by the PM,” said Khursheed Shah, leader of the opposition in the National Assembly.
Imran Khan, leader of the opposition PTI party, said: “We didn’t need to hear such a long story. He could have shown the documents as I have done so.”
Opposition politicians said they would announce on Tuesday their response to Sharif’s speech.

I had thought about suggesting this question myself.  Nawaz Sharif has a habit of shooting himself in the foot.  The Panama Papers revealed ownership of some apartments in London in his childrens' names through a shell company, but this has been common knowledge in the country for at least twenty years. The populace is resigned to having corrupt leadership, and doesn't care too much so long as it can see improvement in everyday life. Compared to the previous government of Mr. Asif Zardari, Sharif was regarded as less corrupt and more capable. However, unlike his predecessor, he doesn't know how to brazen it out. He looks visibly disturbed and seems unable to give a straight and documented answer to a simple question - where did his children get the money to buy those apartments? The opposition is hoping to get him thrown out, with behind-the-scenes blessings of the all powerful army, as they don't want to wait till the scheduled 2018 elections, which they have no guarantee of winning (Nawaz's government has been building motorways and power plants, and there's a lot of Chinese investment in the pipeline that should preserve Sharif's vote bank). Sharif's inability to kill this issue despite the passage of a number of weeks indicates he believes he is vulnerable.
